the growing together of two hydrants are 
formed the medusoide organisms in which 
the bell arises from the exterior hydrant 
and the radial and annular canals from 
the tentacles of another interior hydrant;
the middle part of which is transformed 
in the nutritive tube. (See the applied wood-cut)
High placed Hydrozoa show us the 
higest degree of concentration and its 
consequences. We see it in the greatest spec 
cimen of <u>Tubularia <\u> and in <u>Corymorpha 
nutans <\u>. Both these solitary organisms 
present to us a probable confluence of 
many Hydrants, but at the present time 
we can observe doubtlessly only two Hyd-
rants divided by one zone of many 
small sexual Hydrants (Gynacophors 
or medusoid organisms collected on the many 
small ramous stalks) 2)
2) The single avoiding of this maxima present 
us a little solitary Hydrozoon  <u>Tyarella sin-
gularis Schultze <\u>. It is doubtless a concentrated 
form, but of the very small size.
Now if we will consider in general all the 
cases known at the present time of con-
centrated organisms in relation to 
the simple solitary forms, we schall see 
that <u>in the lowest groups of animals the 
concentrated forms generally preced the
